--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
<snip>
> Yeah, this is interesting.  Here you're inputting
> the
> smallest amount of information necessary for the
> network to play the game successfully.  I'm not sure
> exactly how this would work in practice.
> 
> If, for example, the network outputs two positions,
> and both are empty, there is no state change to the
> table, right?  So you have no input to the network
> (I
> suppose you could input all zeros).
> 
> So do you activate the network again, and take those
> outputs?  Or do you just take the next highest
> outputs
> that correspond to spaces occupied with cards? 

That would correspond to an illegal or invalid move. 
My approach to evolution is very draconian; if a game
playing ANN wants to make an invalid or illegal move I
give it a very low fitness, and end the game right
there.  That ANN will soon be eliminated from the
population.  Usually, in the beginning, that happens
to most of the ANNs, but hopefully not all of them.

<snip>
